quoteFirst: At twelve by my clock the room was dark. We were very busy then. I looked up again at
quoteLast: by _my_ clock here, a minute past twelve by my own watch, which I always keep right by Greenwich, and it's a good chronometer, as you know----"
title: Miracle Gold: A Novel (Vol. 1 of 3)
author: Dowling, Richard, 1846-1898

quoteFirst: “Speaks for himself” every evening this month. On the 1st, he rises at 10:34 a. m., and on the 2d sets at
quoteLast: ; on the 16th, rises at 9:50 a. m., and sets at 11:16 p. m.; and on the 30th, rises at 9:03 a. m., and sets at 10:23 p. m.
title: The Chautauquan, Vol. 05, June 1885, No. 9
author: Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle; Chautauqua Institution; Flood, Theodore L., 1842- [Editor]

quoteFirst: On the 31st she sets at 12:12 a. m.; on the 15th, rises at 11:25 p. m.; on the 31st, sets at
quoteLast: On the meridian, 1st at 5:56¼ p. m.; on the 15th, at 3:58 a. m.; on 30th, at 5:30 p. m. Farthest from the earth, 10th at 7:24 p. m.; nearest the earth on 24th, at 1:36 p. m.
title: The Chautauquan, Vol. 04, May 1884, No. 8
author: Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle; Chautauqua Institution; Flood, Theodore L., 1842- [Editor]

quoteLast: the mail-train came thundering out of nowhere.
title: The end of the trail
author: Powell, E. Alexander (Edward Alexander), 1879-1957
